questions.text: Calculate the anion gap from the following information: Na+ = 137 mEq/L, K+ = 3mEq/L, Ca2+ = 5mEq/L, (PO4)3- = 3mEq/L, HCO3- = 15 mEq/L, Cl- = 110mEq/L
questions.explanation:
Solution:

12 mEq/L The anion gap is the difference between readily measured anion and captions according to Harrison. The anion gap is calculated by [Na+] - {[Cl-] + [HCO3-]}. The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. Here the anion gap in this patient is [137] - {[110] + [15} = 12mEq/L.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause for development of berry aneurysm?
questions.correct_answer: B. Internal elastic lamina layer defect
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Internal elastic lamina layer defect Berry aneurysm A berry aneurysm (also called an intracranial aneurysm or cerebral aneurysm) is a bulging , weakened area in the wall of an artery in the brain , resulting in an abnormal widening, ballooning, or bleb. Because there is a weakened spot in the aneurysm wall , there is a risk for rupture (bursting) of the aneurysm. A normal artery wall is made up of three layers . The aneurysm wall is thin and weak because of an abnormal loss or absence of the muscular layer of the artery wall, leaving only two layers. As an aneurysm develops, it forms a neck with a dome . The arterial internal elastic lamina disappears, the media is thin and connective tissue replaces smooth-muscle cells.

Highyeild:

Complications of ruptured Berry aneurysm Subarachnoid hemorrhage Death Several neurologic deficits Rebleeding leading to Hydrocephalous Diagnosis Angiography CT- Scan scan showing a ruptured Berry aneurysm Treatment Surgical clipping Endovascular Coiling

Extraedge:

Symptoms of ruptured Berry aneurysm Nausea/vomiting Stiff neck Blurred or double vision Sensitivity to light Seizure A drooping eyelid A dilated pupil Pain above and behind the eye Loss of consciousness Confusion Weakness and/or numbness

questions.text: Which of the following is defined as postural hypotension?

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in 20 mmHg SBP after 3 mins of standing

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease in 10 mmHg SBP after 5 mins of standing

options.label: C
options.text: Decrease in 20 mmHg SBP after 1 min of standing

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease in 10 mmHg SBP after 2 mins of standing

questions.correct_answer: A. Decrease in 20 mmHg SBP after 3 mins of standing
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decrease in 20 mmHg SBP after 3 mins of standing Orthostatic hypotension is defined as a decrease in systolic blood pressure of 20 mm Hg or a decrease in diastolic blood pressure of 10 mm Hg within three minutes o f standing when compared with blood pressure from the sitting or supine position. It results from an inadequate physiologic response to postural changes in blood pressure. Treatment includes correcting reversible causes and discontinuing responsible medication , when possible.

Highyeild:

Causes of Orthostatic Hypotension Include:- Neurogenic Parkinson's disease, Diabetic nerve damage, Lewy body disease, One of the most common causes of dementia in older adults), Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS), Vasovagal syncope, Postprandial hypotension Non-neurogenic Heart attack; Aortic stenosis; Vasodilation ; Volume depletion (e.g. Dehydration, Hyperglycemia, Hemorrhage, Vomiting) Medication related vasodilators, diuretics , antidepressants , antipsychotics and dopaminergic drugs , polypharmacy.

Extraedge:

The tilt test assesses someone's response to orthostatic stress (standing upright). This test is a valuable diagnostic test for evaluating patients with syncope . Interpretation Responses to tilt testing : - A 'positive' tilt test is when the patient's syncopal or presyncopal symptoms are reproduced and accompanied by hypotension , bradycardia (relative or otherwise) or both. - Heart rate and blood pressure changes in isolation should not prompt a diagnosis of neurally mediated or OH syncope.

questions.text: The given pattern of EEG is found in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is the most common of the human prion diseases , accounting for approximately 85 % of cases. It has no known cause. Iatrogenic transmission of CJD is associated with prion contaminated human corneas, dura mater grafts , GH, gonadotropins , stereotactic electroencephalography , electrodes and neurosurgical instruments. Clinical features involve:- mental deterioration (dementia, behavioural changes, loss of cortical function) progressive over several months as well as myoclonus, extrapyramidal (hypokinesia) and cerebellar manifestations (ataxia, dysarthria). Diagnosis is by CSF - detection of 14-3-3 protein in the CSF is helpful for the diagnosis. Periodic sharp wave complex in EEG is seen in Creutzfeldt Jakob disease.

Highyeild:

Diagnosis Criteria 1.1 DEFINITE: Progressive neurological syndrome AND Neuropathologically or immunohistochemically or biochemically confirmed 1.2 PROBABLE: 2.1 I + two of Il and typical electroencephalogram* OR 1.2.2 I + two of ll and typical magnetic resonance imaging brain scan® OR 1.2.3 I + two of ll and positive cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) 14-3-3 OR 1.2.4 Progressive neurological syndrome and positive real-time quaking-induced conversion in CSF or other tissues 1.3 POSSIBLE: 1 + two of II + duration <2 years Rapidly progressive cognitive impairment Myoclonus Visual or cerebellar problems Pyramidal or extrapyramidal features Akinetic mutism

Extraedge:

Prion diseases are characterised by the deposition of PrPSc , an abnormally misfolded isoform of the Prion protein, within the nervous system. The mechanism for triggering this conformational change is not known, but the accumulation of this abnormal prion protein leads to: Neuronal degeneration Astrocytic gliosis Spongiform change Resulting in a uniformly fatal neurological disorder

An exudative effusion results from increased capillary permeability characteristic of inflammatory reaction. This type of effusion occurs secondary to conditions such as pulmonary malignancies, pulmonary infections and pulmonary embolization. questions.text: Deep ‘ y’ descent in JVP is seen in all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardiac tamponade ‘a’ wave - atrial contraction ‘c’ wave- bulging of tricuspid valve with ventricular contraction ‘x’ wave- atrial relaxation ‘v’ wave- passive atrial filling ‘y’ wave- atrial emptying with opening of the tricuspid valve Large ‘a’ wave seen in: Tricuspid stenosis, pulmonic stenosis, atrioventricular dissociation. Large ‘V’ wave : Tricuspid regurgitation , Atrial septal defect Cannon ‘a’ wave : complete heart block , premature ventricular contraction , during junctional rhythm and tachycardia Prominent ‘x’ descent : Cardiac tamponade , atrial septal defect Prominent ‘y’ descent: tricuspid regurgitation, constrictive pericarditis, atrial septal defect, restrictive cardiomyopathy. Absent ‘a’ wave : Atrial fibrillation

Highyeild:

Diagnosis: ECG-Electrical alterations JVP waveform- Prominent 'x' descent and absent 'y' descent Chest X-ray: Large, globular or pear-shaped heart with sharp outlines.

Extraedge:

The accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space in a quantity sufficient to cause serious obstruction of the inflow of blood into the ventricles results in cardiac tamponade. The three principal features of tamponade (Beck's triad) are hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent. Paradoxical Pulse: This important clue to the presence of cardiac tamponade consists of a greater than normal (10 mmHg) inspiratory decline in systolic arterial pressure. When severe, it may be detected by palpating weakness or even the disappearance of the arterial pulse during inspiration. Because both ventricles share a tight incompressible covering, i.e..., the pericardial sac and the inspiratory enlargement of the right ventricle cause leftward bulging of the interventricular septum, reducing left ventricular volume, stroke volume, and arterial systolic pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following most associated with respiratory alkalosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Assisted control mode ventilation Assist-control ventilation - The trigger for a machine- delivered breath is the patient’s inspiratory effort, which causes a synchronized breath to be delivered. If no effort is detected over a pre-specified time interval, a timer triggered machine breath is delivered. Limiting factors include the minimum respiratory rate, which is specified by the operations; patients efforts can lead to higher respiratory rates. Because the patient will receive a full tidal breath with each inspiratory efforts, tachypnea due to non-respiratory factors, such as pain, can lead to respiratory alkalosis. In patients with airflow obstruction (asthma, COPD) auto - PEEP (positive end expiratory pressure) can develop.

questions.text: Tigroid appearance of white matter on MRI is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pelizaeus- Merzbacher disease Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is an X-linked leukodystrophy which is characterized by an arrest in myelin development. Due to abnormality of the proteolipid protein (PLP1) gene locus at Xq22. The leopard skin sign (also knows as tigroid pattern or stripe sign) results from dark-spots or stripes (spared perivascular white matter) within bright demyelinated periventricular white matter on T2W images. It is also seen in : Metachromatic leukodystrophy Autosomal recessive spastic ataxia of Charlevoix
